share.share_text:
The Nitty Gritty Dirt Band formed at McCabeâs Record Store in Long Beach in 1966 with a lineup that briefly included Jackson Browne before he made his name as a solo star. By 1967 they were in LA, hoping to make it big while living in a shared house in Beachwood Canyon, which was dubbed by the band and local musicians alike as âThe Dirt House.â
Â 
Newly signed to Liberty Records and playing regular gigs at the Ash Grove (now the Improv on Melrose Ave,) the band recorded their first album at Steinerâs Eight Track studio, home of Hollywoodâs first 8-track machine. In his autobiography, banjo player John McEuen recalled hearing their first hit single on radio station KRLA in 1967. âI was driving down Sunset Boulevard coming up to Vine Street with the radio on loud as I flipped through theÂ stations. One of our songs, âBuy for Me the Rain,â McEuen remembers. âAt 1:03am the jock said âHereâs a new song by that Nitty Gritty Dirt Band!âÂ I almost drove off the road! I went to the All Night Ranch Market,Â spent all twelve dollars I had on food, took it back to the Dirt House, and toldÂ everyone âWeâre gonna be rich! I just heard âRainâ on KRLA!ââ
Â 
On the strength of their first single the group hit the road for a short promotional tour of the East Coast where they met another up-and-coming band in St Louis called the Allman Joys and suggested they return with them to LA. âMy brother and I went down to see them â they were great. Bill convinced them to come to L.A. and give him a shot at managing them,â McEuen said in a later interview. âThey came out and lived with the Dirt Band for the first five months. The Dirt Band had a house. It was a hippie crash pad of the â60s because it was full of musicians and a couple of road guys.â
Â 
Tomorrow Iâll share a Flash Back Friday post about Gregg Allmanâs time in Laurel Canyon after he moved out of the Dirt House and into a girlfriendâs place where he had a hilarious run in with The Doors!

John McEuen was also friends with another Laurel Canyon neigbour, Steve Martin who he met when they were both teens working at Disneyland magic shops. Martin became McEuenâs first banjo student and life-long friend. 

ð· Getty Images

Aerial view of Market Street (1950)

Photo by Fred Lyon

Potrero Hill, circa 1954. Vermont Street looking South to Bayview Hill, newly constructed US101 Freeway. 

Photo by OpenSFHistory / wnp25.0150

share.share_text: First job of the day- shooting a couple of very interesting early Mosrites at Maple Byrneâs place.  Maple is one of the best guitar techs in the business, having worked for Emmylou Harris, Steve Martin, Buddy Miller and many more over his career.  And all the while, heâs been collecting some of the choicest vintage guitars imaginable! Besides photographing the Mosrites, Maple let me play incredible Martins, Gibsons, Wandres, Rickenbackers, etc. Let the sensory overload begin! Thanks Maple!

Husky was equally adept at the genres of traditional honky-tonk, ballads, spoken recitations, and rockabilly pop tunes. He had two dozen Top 20 hits in the Billboard country charts between 1953 and 1975; his versatility and matinee-idol looks propelling a seven-decade entertainment career.
In the 1950s and 60s, Husky's hits included "Gone" and "Wings of a Dove", each reaching No. 1 on the country charts. He also created a comic outspoken hayseed character, Simon Crum; and recorded under the stage name Terry Preston from 1948 to 1953.
In 2010, Husky was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame.(Wiki) 

#ferlinhuskyÂ #countrymusic #country #classiccountry #gospelmusic #dimestoreradio

messages.content: Cute, but inaccurate. "Little Boxes" was written to bemoan the housing tracts in Daly City (particularly the Southern Hills on San Bruno Mountain), not the homes in the Sunset District.

share.share_text:
ð From windswept dunes to rows of homes, the Sunset District redefined itself between the 1920s and 1940s. The transformation was in large part undertaken by Henry Doelger, a local developer with a goal to make homeownership accessible to working-class families. The blocks encompassing 27th â 39th Avenues between Kirkham and Quintara Streets earned the nickname âDoelger City.â Working out of a sales office at 320 Judah Street, Doelger Building Inc went on to build over 16,000 homes in the cityâs west side. Over the years, 6 different styles of Doelger Homes came to be recognized in the Sunset District. Watch closely and take note of these âlittle boxes on the hillside.â

1ï¸â£Mediterranean Revival: The first Doelger home was built in 1927 at 1427 39th Avenue. Themes of this style include open stairwells, stucco exterior, decorations on facade and a barrel front hanging over the garage.
2ï¸â£The Styleocrat: Building trends in the 1940s shifted to the Streamline Moderne style. These homes are sleek, include a tunneled entrance and lack ornamental design. Stained-glass box windows and lines are also noticeable features of the exterior. 
3ï¸â£Rainbow House: This model is color-styled with small balconies unlike its predecessor. Still, many streamlined features are present such as a concealed stairway. 
4ï¸â£The Freedom House:The construction of Doelger homes continued during WW2 despite constraints on materials. Houses were smaller and cheaper than previous models. Notice the semi-sheltered stairway, compact garage and triangular (pitched) roof. 
5ï¸â£The Nantucket: With building materials diverted to war efforts, the practice of simplified design elements continued with these homes. Being taller than other styles gives it a commanding presence in the Avenues as well as larger living space.
6ï¸â£The Westridge: Doelgerâs last style, the colonial-styled homes were designed for Veterans returning back to SF. Doelger ensured his homes were in reach for GIs using VA loans. The exterior features shutters and wood-like finish.

The Arcane Texas Fact of the Day is a little passel of facts about Buddy Holly: 

1) The very first song recorded by the band that would become known as The Beatles was by Texan Buddy Holly. In 1958, The Quarrymen --- John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison, Colin Hanton on drums and John "Duff" Lowe, on piano ---- recorded "That'll Be the Day." 

2) Similarly, one of the very first songs recorded by the Rolling Stones was Buddy's "Not Fade Away." 

3)  Buddy Holly once handmade a leather wallet for Marty Robbins. Robbins' manager was so impressed he asked Buddy if he could order 300 more. Buddy, of course, had no time for that. 

4) I'd always known that Buddy was a huge Elvis fan and would go and see Elvis perform when Elvis played in Lubbock. What I didn't know was that Buddy, who was relentlessly ambitious, made a point of befriending Elvis. âMeeting Elvis was what really inspired Buddy to get things going,â said Bob Montgomery. âEvery time heâd come through, weâd talk to him. We saw GentleÂ­men Prefer Blondes with him one afterÂ­noon at the theater and Elvis got bored afÂ­ter thirty minutes and we left with him.â Bob Montgomery was a songwriting partner and best friend of Buddy Holly, performing with Buddy as the duo "Buddy and Bob" while teenagers in high school.  Initially, they played a variety of bluegrass music, which evolved into rockabilly sounds.

5)  Between February 1957 and April 1958, 14 months, Buddy recorded âThatâll Be the Day,â âNot Fade Away,â âPeggy Sue,â âOh Boy!,â âRave On,â âWellâ¦ All Right,â and âItâs So Easy (to fall in love). Every one of them is a timeless classic.

Shown here: Buddy Holly without his glasses in 1957.
Leon Russell when he was still Russell Bridges, Tulsa 1959. #leonrussell #russellbridges #rockers #sessionmen #okies #inventingrocknroll #tulsa

share.share_text: #merletravis #royclark 1982

Famed neurologist and author Oliver Sacks lived in Topanga Canyon in the early 1960 before he became known for his seminal 1973 book (and 1990 movie) âAwakenings.â As a young student at UCLA in the sixties, Sacksâ focus was on experimental and hallucinogenic drugs, study that would one day go on to inform his most famous neurology work.

During his time in Topanga, Sacks regularly experimented with a variety of drugs in between studying and workouts on Veniceâs famed Muscle Beach. In an article for the New Yorker in 2012, Sacks describes beginning his exploration when a friend offered him a joint. âI took two puffs and was transfixed by what happened then. I gazed at my hand, and it seemed to fill my visual field, getting larger and largerâ¦ stretched across the universe,â Sacks writes. âMy first pot experience was marked by a mixture of the neurological and the divine.â

From there Sacks moved on to LSD and morning-glory seeds, which were readily available in Topanga, before a friend suggested he try Artane, a synthetic drug that Sacks knew was used in the treatment of Parkinsonâs disease. âSo, one Sunday morning I counted out twenty pillsâ¦ and sat down to await the effect,â he recounts. âWould the world be transformed, newborn, as Huxley described in âThe Doors of Perception,â and as I myself had experienced with mescaline and LSD?â Instead Sacks experienced intense hallucinations that included making eggs for friends who turned out to not be there, a helicopter dropping his parents off in his backyard and a casual conversation with a spider.

After Sacks left Topanga for New York, his experimentation with drugs continued, this time with large doses of amphetamines. While working in a migraine clinic, he found a book on the subject that he began to read while high. Experiencing intense hallucinations that made him feel as though he was inside the body of the author, Sacks realized this field of study was where his attentions should turn. âBit by bit, I started to write my own book,â Sacks writes. âThe joy I got from this was real - infinitely more substantial than the vapid mania of amphetamines - and I never took amphetamines again.â

ð· Unknown

#oliversacks

documenting Shibuyaâs sleeping meltdown with @shibuyameltdown

For over 10 years, the instagram page @shibuyameltdown has been posting a rarely documented side of Japan.

The scenes of tired & drunk salaryman passing out in the streets of Shibuya present a stark contrast.â¨â¨On one side, they highlight the safety of Tokyoâs streets, where youâd probably wake up with most of your belongings neatly beside you, even a water bottle or two from a kind stranger.â¨â¨On the other hand it highlights Japanâs toxic corporate work culture, showing how weekly nomikai sessions leave exhausted salarymen passed out on the streets of Shibuya instead of their beds at home.
John Goodman

After returning home from WWII, Glen Bell hoped to open a taco spot. According to writer Gustavo Arellano, who researched this history, Bellâs wife cautioned that people wouldnât want to order tacos from a white guy, Bell spent his evenings trying to reverse engineer the tacos from Mitla Cafe. The cafeâs owner quickly figured out what Bell was up to and invited him into the kitchen. After spending about a year at Mitla, Bell branched out and opened his own taco place about a mile-and-a-half away. He went on to open Taco Bell. And one of his former employees opened Del Taco.
#TacoBell #History

The Arcane Texas Fact of the Day:

Roy Orbison was a huge fan of Monty Python. Roy was one of the five musicians who made up The Traveling Wilburys, the others being George Harrison, Tom Petty, Bob Dylan, and Jeff Lynne. The supergroup was George Harrison's idea. George had worked  with members of Monty Python on various productions by his company HandMade Films since the late 1970s, and he appreciated both Roy's gift for impersonations and Roy's ability to recite entire sketches by the troupe.

Excited to share the imaginative visual art of @gercoderuijter whose art book, âGrid Correctionsâ provides a stunning and thoughtful meditation on how America conformed its landscape to a grid following the ideas of Thomas Jefferson during the 1780s, which we still live with today. I feature De Ruijterâs stop-motion film of the same name in this post to help illustrate just how hard surveyors had to work to make the imagined grid of 6x6 townships fit onto the western 2/3s of the American landscape. #maps #googlemaps #stopmotion #americanhistory #drtimshistory #cartography

All hail the great Cosimo Matassa, the genius who recorded 98% of the music of New Orleans from the late 1940s through the late 1960s.  This guy made your favorite records by Fats Domino, Little Richard, Smiley Lewis, Lee Dorsey, Dr. John, Aaron Neville, Art Neville, Allen Toussaint, Irma Thomas, Shirley and Lee, Frankie Ford, and about a thousand others.  The sound he got was THE coolest sound, like a party was going off in your living room, and he did it without a great deal of equipment.  This mid-1950s shot shows him with a tiny 4-channel Dukane mixer, a Cinema EQ unit, and not much else.  No air conditioning back then, so you know it was a thousand degrees in there, hence the t-shirt.

In later years, Cosimo managed the family grocery in the French Quarter.  One morning around 1999 or 2000, I walked over there after a gig in New Orleans the night before and asked if I could meet Cosimo.  A few minutes later, he came out of the back, a stout little Yoda of a man, and dutifully answered my questions for 15 minutes.

He wanted no credit for his role in creating some of Americaâs most iconic Rhythm and Blues, Rock ânâ Roll, Soul and Funk.

âIt was all about THOSE musicians.  Anybody could have put a few microphones in front of those guys and it would have sounded good.â Despite his protestations to the contrary, no one has ever made records like THAT ever again.  He captured lightning in a bottle.

Iâm really glad I got to meet him. Cosimo Matassa, 1926-2014

The 2024 Japanese stationery awards announced their top four products.

The uni-ball one P pens won the design award. They are known for their cute look, smooth writing, and food-inspired colors like grape, orange, and banana. The collection recently added four new versions, including two with rose gold clips.

The Campus Flat Kimochii Notebook received the functionality award. It can open flat, making it easier to write and photograph notes. The company took three years to develop this practical notebook.

The Ukanmuri Clip earned the idea award for its ideal clipping strength for books and notebooks. Its unique and cute design became popular on Japanese social media.

The grand award went to the Pentel Mattehop pens, the best Japanese stationery of 2024. These pens work like mini graphic markers and produce a matte finish, perfect for writing on photos and dark surfaces, making them great for decorations.
#writing #studying #stationery

share.share_text: Farewell to another friend and hero, legendary Sun Records drummer J.M. âJimmyâ Van Eaton. I wrote a very long tribute that I posted on my Facebook page, if you want to check it out. He was an incredible drummer, a master of taste and âfeelâ in his playing. He was an expert at swinging and rocking at the same time, something that is virtually lost with all modern drummers. The guy played on about 50 million selling hits! Youâve probably heard him every day of your life, and didnât even realize it. He shall be greatly missed. Rest easy, my friend.  Condolences to all of his family.

A highlight of my career and life would be this moment with my dear friend @fatsdominoofficial in my 1985 film âWalking to New Orleansâ. Fats was the greatest, the kindest and the best ever. I love him, I miss him.

share.share_text:
From the 1920s through the 1960s, neon signs blazed all over San Franciscoânearly the entire length of Market Street and much of Broadwayâwith displays that became ever more elaborate as businesses tried to compete for attention with their radiant fixtures. But starting in the 1970s, affordable, easy-to-maintain light-emitting diodes (LEDs) came into popular use, leading to neonâs decline. 

Luckily, thereâs an ongoing movement, spearheaded by organizations like the advocacy group San Francisco Neon and supported by businesses like Neon Works, not only to protect our cityâs existing neon but also to add to its glowing portfolio. One of the best ways to ensure neonâs survival, according to San Francisco Neon co-founder Randall Ann Homan, is to patronize the businesses that take the trouble of maintaining the signs.

You have plenty to choose from in the city: grocery stores and steakhouses, cocktail bars and movie theaters. So use neon as an excuse to get out and explore those new-to-you corners of the city and tap the link in our bio for some more photos of the cityâs most spectacular neon signs.

share.share_text:
A belated happy 100th birthday to the Vista Theatre, which first opened as Bard's Hollywood Theatre on October 9th, 1923.

Intended as both a cinema and a vaudeville theatre, the Hollywood Bard was built by downtown theatre proprietor Lou Bard who'd had great success with his College and Hill Street theatres and was looking to expand. Setting his sights on Hollywood, Bard bought up a plot of land at Hollywood & Sunset that had once been part of the backlot for director D. W. Griffith's Reliance-Majestic Film Studios - in fact, it now stands approximately where the towering set of Babylon had been built for the 1916 film "Intolerance" (the studio itself was located where the Vons now stands across the street). Bard then brought in architect Lewis A. Smith, who designed it with a Spanish Colonial Revival exterior, and an Egyptian Revival interior, inspired both by the success of Grauman's Egyptian Theatre and the world's fascination with the discovery of King Tutankhamen's tomb in 1922.

When the theatre opened, 100 years ago yesterday, the opening night program consisted of the premiere of the Baby Peggy comedy short "Tips," filmed nearby at the then-new Ambassador Hotel, followed by a sneak peek of the Universal comedy-drama "The Wild Party," starring Gladys Walton. Vaudeville performances and other shorts also peppered the evening, which was reported as "a fine entertainment for all, and altogether too much for one evening." This first photo was taken that night.

The theatre became the Vista in 1933 and operated through the 1950s, then it became an arthouse theatre in 1960, and then as a porno theatre in 1961. In 1980, the Vista re-opened as a mainstream cinema, but closed in 2020 due to COVID. 

It was purchased by Quentin Tarantino in June of 2021, and is undergoing renovations, hopefully to re-open soon.

Photos:

Jesse McReynolds has passed away at the age of 92.

McReynolds was born in 1929 in Coeburn, Virginia. His grandfather, Charles, led a group called The Bull Mountain Moonshiners, who made their initial recordings at the 1927 Bristol Sessions. 

Around 1947, Jesse started performing with his brother Jim as The McReynolds Brothers. In 1952, the brothers began recording for Capitol Records under the name Jim and Jesse. The brothers recorded and performed together until Jimâs death in 2002.

Jesse continued to perform as a solo artist after his brotherâs passing including making appearances as a member of the Grand Ole Opry. In 2019, he celebrated 55 years of Opry membership. 

Here is a video of Jim and Jesse performing âParadiseâ in 1976.

#JesseMcReynolds #Virginia #GrandOleOpry

share.share_text:
Itâs been a few weeks now since @thetyee published this article about us, written sympathetically by the very lovely @olamideolaniyan. Chris from @pfbvan and Kim from @thepaperhound were both interviewed about me and were incredibly kind and generous. I consider myself lucky to call them not just my colleagues, but also friends and mentors to myself and Calen. The wave of well-wishes we received from this article was so overwhelming to me that I had to put my phone down for a couple of days, and Iâm still playing a bit of catch up on messages (as you can see itâs taken me some time even to post this). It really proves to me that we fill a niche for a local bookshop here in Gibsons, as well as my own limitations for how much time I can spend gratefully answering messages before I need a break to recharge myself. I have to accept from this info that I may never be Heather from Chapters/Indigo, but I can still be important in the place where I stand. Weâve had so many new faces in, and so many proud regulars congratulating us on the publicity. Thank you so much for all the kind words. All press is good press, I hear, but surely something like this is very good indeed. It certainly feels like it.
.
PS thank you so much to @folkfotos for the awesome pics of the store!

RIP Johnny Powers, one of the last original Sun Rockabilly artists. His âLong Blonde Hairâ still stands as one of the most goosebumps-inducing rockabilly singles of the 1950s. Johnny was one of the first original 1950s artists I ever saw, he came out to Southern California shortly after I moved there in 1991, backed by Big Sandy and the Fly-Rite Trio with T.K. Smith on guitar. Man, we were all 30 years younger then, including Johnny, and I remember Johnny and the Fly-Rites just tearing the roof off the joint, 3 or 4 nights in a row. Such a great memory. Johnny was pretty loyal to his Detroit bands over the years, so I didnât get a lot of chances to back him up, but I did back him up at least twice, what a thrill! Also, I will mention his other claim to fameâ he was a fixture in the early years of Motown, and he had a great story about those stomping feet with tons of reverb that you hear at the beginning of âWhere Did Our Love Goâ by the Supremes. Thatâs Johnny, up in the Motown echo chamber, stomping his feet as hard as he could. Youâve probably heard that record a million times, but youâll hear it differently now, I promise! RIP Johnny, you left behind a lot of great music and memories.

Sunday night, @JerryLeeLewisTheKiller was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame. 

Lewis, a singer and dazzling piano player, is a pillar of rock & roll, but he also embraced country music from the very beginning as an essential part of his distinctive, dynamic style. The Ferriday, Louisiana, native scored two massive country, pop, and R&B hits with âWhole Lot of Shakinâ Going Onâ and âGreat Balls of Fireâ within months of signing with @SunRecordCompany in late 1956. He also became known for his rollicking and rowdy live performances.

Lewis earned thirty-four Top Twenty country hits between 1968 and 1981, cementing his reputation as an exceptional country entertainer.

He was inducted along with #JoeGalante and #KeithWhitley.

Visit CountryMusicHallofFame.org to learn more (link in bio).

Keith Whitley was born on this day in 1955 in Bedford, Kentucky. 

Here is a young Keith photographed with Ricky Skaggs and Ralph Stanleyâs mother, Lucy, in the late 1960s.

share.share_text:
Today, Ramblinâ Jack Elliott turns 90 years old. The late, great Johnny Cash once said that Jackâs, âgot a song and a friend for every mile behind himâ and (despite Johnnyâs propensity for tall tales) I believe it through and through. Student of Guthrie, father of Bob Dylan (or so he has been known to say), the Brooklyn cowboy, sailor of highways and rider of seas has made a lifetime of ramblinâ, gamblinâ and singing his songs.Â 

Just about every folk and country music star of the past 75 years has broken bread, shared a bottle of Cutty Sark with, or crossed paths with the inimitable Mr. Jack Elliott. In the recent past, our friend (and one of my favorite pen pals) @joshokeefeofficial shared a stage, some songs, and a swig or two of Guinness with the man who Woody Guthrie said, âsounds more like me than I do.â Josh was kind enough to send me a sketch he had done of âCowboy Jack, lookinâ youngâ and it is one of my favorite pieces of art in my collection, on account of Joshâs generosity and talent, but also because of the significance of Jackâs influence on the world of North American folk music I love.Â Â 

Our clip this week was selected from the 1965 episode of Pete Seegerâs Rainbow Quest featuring Ramblinâ Jack. The song is, âTalkinâ Sailor Bluesâ a rendition of Woody Guthrieâs âTalkinâ Sailor.â Nearly 10 years earlier, in 1956, Jack released âWoody Guthrieâs Blues,â a collection of songs penned by Guthrie and recorded in Ewan MacCollâs motherâs living room by Alan Lomax. It is a gem of a song and a treasure trove of an album. âWoody Guthrieâs Bluesâ was released in 1963 as, âTalkinâ Woody Guthrieâ with a variant track arrangement, and again in 2002, when it was released on CD. Now, I cannot find the original 1956 8â LP for sale, but would love to add it to my collection. If youâve got a line on one, shoot me a message, Iâd greatly appreciate it.

In honor of Ramblinâ Jackâs birthday, letâs share some of our favorite songs, albums, performances, stories and tall tales about the legend himself. Drop those comments in the section below. We look forward to hearing from you.Â 

Stay safe, talk soon.Â 

-Dakota Silva
(@silvadakota)

#folkarchives #ramblinjackelliott

Yasuri texture / Matte finish 

One of my favorite time to make a marriage ring is to hear how their love has grown. He showed her that âwill you marry me?â board inside of Enoden during Kamakura trip. Wish I took the same train and just watched them...!!! Thank you so much for sharing happiness, and letting me make a bridge to the next chapter of your love story.

Episode 48 â Hiro Umetani, Kyomai Japanese Traditional Dancer

On this episode weâre gonna examine a notable Japanese traditional dance that is often peformed by the Geisha and Maiko. Meet Hiro, (or her stage name, âZuiou Shinozukaâ). She is a traditional Japanese dancer/instructor trained from the oldest Kyomai dance school in Kyoto. She is currently an ambassador to promote her art form as well as collaborating with musicians abroad in hopes to preserve the cultural importance of traditional Japanese dance.  For more information please check out her website:  zuioushinozuka.com

Kneejerk
â¢
ð½ by @bakedlikepie 

A woman knocks a black bear off a block wall to save her pets. 

Friends, I really struggled to justify posting this. I do not think promoting this behavior is a good idea because I can totally see it getting someone (or more likely a lot of bears) killed one day. 

I ultimately decided to use the virality of this video in an attempt to innoculate against future occurrences, in the hope that if presented with a choice like this, you'll choose the path that doesn't involve putting your body within striking distance of a momma bear with vulnerable cubs. Ever. 

So first off, let me go ahead and state unequivocally that you should never ever ever approach any wild animal, especially those with offspring, unless all other options have been exhausted.

On the flip side, I also understand the impulse to save your pets. In this case, it worked out the best way possible (for the human at least) but she was soo damn lucky to get out of there in one piece. 

Protective instincts are on full display in this one, and I truly believe that the bear's fixation on the dogs allowed the woman to get close enough to tip the scales in her favor long enough to get the dogs and herself out of harms way.

Just keep in mind that this could have ended very differently, so please don't try this.

#natureismetal
#keepnaturemetal
